#Text=Zimbabwe cabinet meets without MDC ministers after boycott
#Text=Tuesday , October 20 , 2009

#Text=Zimbabwean president Robert Mugabe led a cabinet meeting on Tuesday without the presence of unity partner Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai , who was out of the country on a regional tour to appeal for help with mediation .

#Text=This comes after Tsvangirai and his Movement for Democratic Change ( MDC ) party pulled out of the unity government several days ago , protesting what they called " dishonest and unreliable " behaviour by Mugabe .

column1: #Text=Zimbabwe state media reported on Tuesday that President Mugabe will not recognise Tsvangirai 's suspension of ties with the government until he is formally informed .
#Text=The state-owned daily newspaper , The Herald , quoted Mugabe 's spokesman , George Charamba , as saying Tsvangirai is still prime minister and is expected to attend cabinet meetings .
#Text=“ Government is not run through media statements .
#Text=In the same way that President Mugabe formally appointed him to the post of Prime Minister
#Text=he must also communicate any decision to disengage or whatever it is they are calling it , in a formal manner , " Charamba said .

#Text=Tsvangirai , who  disengaged " from the country 's unity government last week , was accused by the newspaper of traveling without cabinet approval .

column1: #Text=The leader of the MDC party is on a ten-day trip of Southern African Development Community countries , who helped to negotiate the troubled power sharing agreement in Zimbabwe .
#Text=Tsvangirai is not due to return to Zimbabwe until sometime next week .

#Text=According to The Herald , government officials said that Tsvangirai had attempted to obtain cabinet authority for his trip while en route to the airport , but was told that it was too late to receive it .

#Text=However , University of Zimbabwe political science professor John Makumbe said he believed Tsvangirai 's partial withdrawal from the national unity government was long overdue and ZANU-PF 's reaction is mere posturing . "

#Text= We are determined to give this government a fighting chance because in our mind there is no plan B , " Mutambara said .

column1: #Text=Tsvangirai announced last week that his party would not withdraw from the unity government altogether , but would boycott the executive branch whose ministries it shares with the ZANU-PF party .
#Text=He cited the reluctance of Mugabe to implement matters that had been agreed to in the so-called Global Political Agreement , which brought the national unity government to power .
#Text=Among the outstanding issues is the appointment of governors and the alleged harassment of his party members and Members of Parliament .
#Text=His announcement came two days after agriculture deputy minister designate Roy Bennett was arrested and re-detained on charges of insurgency and terror .
#Text=Bennett has since been released on bail , but Tsvangirai has said his party will not participate in government until all the issues he raised have been resolved .
